module.param: PostProcess - reusing one set of search results for more than one purpose

module.name: HTML
module.param: Here we show how you can configure static postProcess arguments to hang several different elements off of a single search.

module.name: Search
module.param: index=_internal source="*metrics.log" group="per_*_thruput" | stats count avg(eps) as avgEps sum(kb) as sumKB by group,series

module.name: PostProcess
module.param: search group="per_source_thruput" | sort - sumKB | fields series, sumKB | rename series as source | rename sumKB as "Total KB"

module.name: PostProcess
module.param: search group="per_sourcetype_thruput" | sort - avgEps | head 10 | fields series, avgEps | rename series as sourcetype | rename avgEps as "Events Per Second"

module.name: PostProcess
module.param: stats sum(sumKB) as Total | eval Total=round(Total/(1024),3) | eval Total=Total + " MB"

module.name: HTML
module.param:
Notes

  1. Although we're only running one search on this page, we're using postProcess so that we can use those search results in three different ways. (As with other views, you should view the XML source of this page to see how it's done.)
  2. If you have not already read our Introduction to Post process searches, do so now.
  3. The Paginator module is not smart enough to account for the presence of the postProcess arg. Use the Sideview "Pager" module instead.
  4. Likewise, if you want to use the ResultsHeader to report the filtered count it cannot do that; it will report the unfiltered count instead. And even the SimpleResultsHeader module (using $$count$$ in the headerFormat param) will also report the unfiltered count. Use an HTML module with a $$results.count$$ token instead.
